special_result_for_divider
Summary

Generates the final result of the adder when at least one operand is a special case (e.g., ±infinity, ±zero). Handles cases like Inf + Inf or Inf - Inf.

Parameters
M

Mantissa width.

E

Exponent width.

special_case

Number of supported special cases.

Ports
X

Operand X (custom floating-point format).

Y

Operand Y (custom floating-point format).

X_special_case

Code identifying if X is a special case (0 = not special).

Y_special_case

Code identifying if Y is a special case (0 = not special).

special_result

Result of the operation considering only the special cases.

Special case identifiers

Constant encoding of recognized special cases.

Variables
CASE_NONE
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_NONE = 0

No special case.

CASE_INF_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_INF_P = 1

Positive infinity.

CASE_INF_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_INF_N = 2

Negative infinity.

CASE_ZERO_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ZERO_P = 3

Positive zero.

CASE_ZERO_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ZERO_N = 4

Negative zero.

CASE_ONE_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ONE_P = 5

Positive one.

CASE_ONE_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ONE_N = 6

Negative one.

Special result constants

Constant encoding of special results for the adder.  These are used when at least one operand is a special case.

localparam logic [E+M:0]
   POS_INF  = {1'b0, {E{1'b1}}, {M{1'b1}}},
   NEG_INF  = {1'b1, {E{1'b1}}, {M{1'b1}}},
   POS_ZERO = {1'b0, {E+M{1'b0}}},
   NEG_ZERO = {1'b1, {E+M{1'b0}}};
Special result generation

This block selects the correct result when one or both operands are classified as special cases.

It covers combinations such as:

  • x / Zero  → returns neg infinity

  • x / 1  → returns x

  • x / inf  → returns zero

  • inf / inf → returns neg infinity

This mechanism ensures that special cases are handled deterministically before any general arithmetic is performed.  It allows the rest of the floating-point divider to assume that both operands are normal if this path is not taken.
